item.name: The Boy Who Was Raised as a Dog by Bruce D. Perry
item.description:
618.92 Perry
Focused on how trauma effects children, this covers many stories in detail from which people have faced during their younger years. Covers topics interpretively such as the neuroscience and developmental theory behind how trauma effects a person, especially those who are children. This is written narratively, and covers many forms of trauma, but brings home a clear message about resilience and recovering from trauma.

item.name: Guiding children's social development : theory to practice by Kostelnik, Marjorie J.
item.description:
155.4 Gui
Developed to guide working with children in a classroom, it covers topics such as improving self esteem and interpreting student behavior.

item.name: The first three years and beyond : brain development and social policy by Zigler, Edward, 1930-
item.description:
305.231 Zig DAVIE
Written targeting parents and policymakers, this gives a background on how childrens' brains develop and addressing problems that occur during early childhood development. The key chapter for this is chapter 6, which covers Child Abuse and the Brain

item.name: Toxic parents : overcoming their hurtful legacy and reclaiming your life by Forward, Susan
item.description:
362.829 Forward DAVIE
For those that have struggled through childhood with maltreatment, this gives context to how the trauma is not the child's fault. For those in education, medical fields, or generally researching about trauma, this can give context to what abuse and neglect does, and signs to listen for people casually mentioning that indicate that home was not or is not safe.

item.name: Raising Cain : protecting the emotional life of boys by Kindlon, Daniel J. (Daniel James), 1953-
item.description:
1999, Davidson, 305.23 Kindlon
2000, Davie, 305.23 Kindlon DAVIE
The context that boys grow up in commonly forces them to reject their own emotions and not develop emotional literacy. For those who work with boys, this supplements knowledge about improving children's emotional literacy and addressing this at school and home.

item.name: The lost boy : a foster child's search for the love of a family by Pelzer, David J.
item.description:
362 Pelzer
This comes from a primary source discussing the effects of losing the birth family as a foster child. It covers topics such as the assumption by many that foster children are too troublesome and some that care for them feel resentment towards the children simply because they are a foster child.

item.name: Your body belongs to you by Spelman, Cornelia
item.description:
J 613.6 Spe
This covers education on sexual abuse and informing children that they are allowed to say no to being touched.

item.name: The scared child : helping kids overcome traumatic events by Brooks, Barbara, 1937-
item.description:
155.93 Bro DAVIE
Working with kids, be it as a parent, teacher, social worker, or other position that is in contact with children often, this covers tactics for encouraging children to express their fear in a way that helps them cope.

item.name: A child called "it" : one child's courage to survive by Pelzer, David J.
item.description:
362.7 Pel DAVIE
Covers an extreme case of child abuse, discussing the events of what happened clearly. Using this as a resource for having clear trauma experiences to refer to can solidify understanding of other materials discussing working with others who have experienced forms of trauma such as abuse and neglect. Despite it being extreme, it also can give context to individual events that may lead to developmental trauma.

item.name: The Color Purple by Walker, Alice, 1944-
item.description:
F Wal
Even though this is fiction, it provides insight into how sexual abuse effects those who experience it, especially the sense of isolation. When working with those who have been abused, this is a viewport into how abuse changes a person's abilities to speak for themselves through the training by those who abused them into believing no one will help.
